Billy is the legal guru. Also partner of a successful restaurant Social Kitchen and Brewery in San Francisco by night. So between the clients, and the people he meets and greets, he needs to use P.S. to store his business cards electronically so he can quickly pull it up and reference a contact right away.
 
Abhi Agrawal - 1 numbers guy CPA
Abhi got his chartered accountancy license in India and said that wasn't enough. So he moved to the US and got his CPA. He loves the numbers world so many clients,  he needs his business card repository right by him at all times.

 
 

Bahurudeen Mohamed - 1 Techie
Bahu worked for one of the earliest startups in India as early as 1998. The company was developing ecommerce website even before Amazon was a big thing. He since moved from India to the US and helped two startups get off the ground successfully. He's met so many friends at tech shows and conventions. He said something needs to be done electronically to swipe his card. Bahu invented the swipe function of our business cards on our P.S. app.
 


 

Gwen Chua - 1 Real Estate Guru


 
Gwen sells homes for his clients in San Mateo County. From his buyers to sellers, his clients are his contacts.  He would love for all of them  to use P.S. so they can store his business contact as a reference  anytime they need anything Real Estate related and to share his wealth  of Real Estate related contacts.  Looking for a reliable plumber, a  contractor or maybe a housekeeper?!
Check out our website, http://www.persociety.com 
Check out our giveaways on the gallery.
 
Kindle Fire Case/ with P.S. Mobile Preloaded

 
 

Persociety Ipod Touch Preloaded with Persociety Mobile App

story:
What Is Tipsy?

We’re an on-demand alcohol delivery service.

We start your night, keep it going, and make sure you don’t miss out on a good time. Driving in traffic, waiting in line, dealing with angry employees - all of that makes for a horrible experience! 

Instead, open the app, pick what you want to drink, and we’ll see you in 30 mins. 


We are in the app store and currently serving the greater Los Angeles area.        

Your contribution will help jumpstart our ultimate goal to serve all major cities across the United States.          

  


Perks

Tipsy Cocktails and Games

Learn how to make 10 cocktails in minutes that will really get your date excited ;) 
We'll also send you our top 10 favorite drinking games so there's never a dull moment.

Tipsy Starter Kit:
One tote bag, two coasters, one flask, and a bottle opener




Unlimited Free Deliveries



Tipsy Engraved Whiskey Glass



Wine Club

Get 2 bottles of wine per month on us for 3 months. Must live in the greater Los Angeles Area.


Arsenic Photoshoot

Get invited to the Arsenic house in the Hollywood Hills. You'll get a behind the scenes experience at one of the infamous Arsenic photoshoots. Drinks will be provided by Tipsy.


The Arsenic Models will be doing Deliveries and hanging out with you and your friends to get the party started. You'll also be featured on ArsenicTv. Get your cameras ready ;)

Arsenic is one of todays hottest online magazines. Check them out here...


What Are People Saying About Us?




Our Plans...

What are we going to do with $20,000?  Great question...

  • Build the Google Play Version (we don't discriminate). 
  • A redesign of the website to allow online orders.
  • iPods:  We need to provide every store we work with an iPod touch, which in turn will allow us to serve them with ease.
  • We will be hiring drivers to give you an amazing experience every time you order.
  • We need to seek legal counsel every time we expand, as laws frequently change within every city and state.
  • Marketing - what's the point of having the best delivery app if no one knows about it? We need to spread the word!

What Impact Will Tipsy Make?

We are glad you asked...

  • Our company will drive more business to Mom and Pop liquor stores, so they can keep the lights on.
  • Every city added to our network will create jobs to further help the community.
  • Tipsy will continue to work hard to keep drunk drivers from getting behind the wheel.


      

What Are Our Challenges?

The problem we face is that the sale and distribution of alcohol changes in every city and state.  We need to make sure we comply with all liquor laws to make this dream a reality -  we can't do it without your help!  


THANK YOU!

Thank you for taking the time to check out our campaign! Believe me when we say every dollar counts.  We would really appreciate it if you could hit the share links to let as many people as possible know about Tipsy.  Together, we will change the way alcohol is delivered.  

If there are any questions, please send us an email support@drinktipsy.com
Also, don't forget to follow us on Instagram ;)

story:
It’s the time! We are live on IndieGoGo again. Check out our new campaign!

 

Let’s face it, cables, old development platform, expensive sensors, a breadboard, a power source, more cables… this just doesn’t fit with the new generation of developers. We want to change this! We have two main ideas behind the watchX:

1- Use what you make!
2- Learn Industrial design!
3- Be the next Elon MUSK (just kidding, remember I said two).

 

watchX is delivered to the customers all around the world!

 

 

What is watchX?

watchX is an Arduino/Scratch compatible wearable development board that will extend your imagination because you wear it! You can use watchX as a regular watch when you don’t use it for development purposes. It has a freaking cool design and mind blowing watch firmware that is packed into a cool design.

OK! It’s time to move on from the desk to the wrist. We are so excited for what you can do with watchX!

 

* The referance 3D model for 3D Printing will be published.

* Educational video about how to design your own case is coming soon.

* The watchX that you see in the pictures are prototypes.
Final watchX will be the same as 360 3D model.

 

It’s Arduino compatible!

We all love Arduino, it’s simple, there is a lot of documentation available, it’s just amazing. watchX without Arduino is unthinkable. watchX is Arduino compatible, this means; when you plug the watchX to your computer all you need to do is to open up your favorite Arduino IDE and start programming.

 

It’s Scratch compatible!

We all love our kids, we care them a lot. We want them to eat the healthiest food and we wish the best for their future. Actually, there is more you can do than just wishing the best! watchX is Scratch compatible so that kids can get their hands on watchX easily. watchX engages kids a lot; because, they use what they make! This drives them to develop next day and increase their excitement!

Result: happy young developers.

 

Advanced users:

watchX is a development platform for all, we did not limited watchX to Arduino and Scratch. You can compile your code using Atmel Studio and program the watchX. All the low-level code and libraries will be provided so that you can focus on your idea. There are lots of things we can do together!

 

 

Grand Vision

watchX and its current state is just the tip of the iceberg. Only a huge community of developers and makers can unlock the true potential of watchX. This is exactly what we dream of, a huge community of developers exchanging information, developing cool apps and games. There are cool features waiting to be developed such as a mobile app that will allow watchX to be used as a smartwatch. Remember great things in life never done by a single person, they are done by a team of people.

 

Do what you can’t!

We tend to believe that great stuff will come up from extraordinary people, this is not true!! With the right tools and gadgets, anyone can accomplish great things. It’s just a matter of taking the first step!

We believe that watchX will serve for anyone to accomplish, next big thing in wearables, electronics or industrial design! The true potential of watchX is within you! Here is just a few example of what you could build:

 

Specifications

 

Programming the Watch

watchX is a development board for users from a variety of age. We can simply divide users into two categories. Advanced users and beginner users.

Beginner Users:

watchX is Arduino compatible. It will be loaded with Arduino Uno Bootloader for beginners. To program the watch, just download the Arduino IDE and plug the watchX to the USB port. USB drivers will automatically be installed. Then you should choose Arduino Uno from tools/boards/arduino uno, then you can write your own code or simply download a sample sketch from our web site and program the watch.

watchX is scratch compatible. You just download the Scratch and install the firmware required to be installed to watchX in order for the watch to communicate with Scratch. You can choose “pre-load Scratch firmware” option while you are purchasing watchX or you can install it by yourself, it’s easy. Just copy provided code, paste it to Arduino IDE and send the code to watch, you are all set.

Advanced Users:

watchX has ISP programming capability. You can develop your code through atmel studio and program the IC through ISP. Remember that you need an ISP programmer for doing this, any Arduino can be used as ISP programmer as well. We will provide you a detailed explanation about how to develop your code at Atmel studio and program the IC using ISP. You can simply burn the IC with arduino uno bootloader and use it as arduino uno as well.

Software

watchX firmware you saw on video:
watchX has an excellent firmware thanks to ZAK, almost everything is animated nice and beautiful . 
watchX firmware has apps like:

Alarms: You can set-up up to 10 alarms, each alarm has the hour, minute and which the days of the week it should be active on.

Flashlight: It is crazy, we recommend you to use it at a party, it’s cool.

Stopwatch: You can start and stop stopwatch, it can also run in the background.

Games: We have two fun games that you saw on video, it’s amusing what this little puppy can do isn’t it:)

Settings: Settings have four sub-categories. You can increase or decrease display brightness. You have volume control in UI, alarms and hour beep. You can set display sleep time-out to increase battery life. And you can invert the screen also you can turn on/off animations.

An app that you can run your own code: This app will run your own code. There is a section in the software where you can write your own code. Once you write your code and send it to the watch, you can navigate to the app from menu to run your code. You can also add other apps to menu.

We designed watchX, software in mind. We tried to use ICs that are popular in Arduino/maker community for sample code availability and IC familiarity. For instance, we used MPU 6050 as accelerometer/gyroscope.

If you are not satisfied with our sample code, you can reach lot’s of sample code sources online like Adafruit or Sparkfun.

Charging/Battery Life:

watchX equipped with intelligent charging circuitry. When you connect the watch to a USB port or another power source, charging circuitry disconnects the battery from an electrical load of watchX and starts to charge it. Required power of watchX during charging is supplied from the power source. This way, the battery does not discharge while charging. When battery is fully charged, charging IC stops charging.

This gives you the advantage of using your watchX for different applications where you need long constant power at remote locations. You can use watchX without worrying about battery overcharge! In case of electrical black out the watchX battery will kick in.

While the watch is running, microcontroller tries to go to sleep as much as possible. In sleep mode, power consumption can be around 0,8 mA - 2 mA. In sleep mode microcontroller turns the OLED display off and goes into power down sleep mode where it is only woken by either a button press, an RTC alarm or USB being plugged in. In this state, microcontroller draws around 100nA. In sleep mode overall current draw is around 6uA. In normal usage current draw is around 10mA this can increase up to 70mA.

        - During sleep mode(6uA): ~2.8 years
        - Typical usage (10mA): ~15 hours
        - High (65mA): ~ 2 hours.

*If the watch is used in active mode for 1 minute a day and volume channels set to minimum, watch battery should last around 1 year and 3 months.

Hardware

Let’s start with MCU, we used atmega328p to cover all users from a variety of age. We are aware of the atmega328p is a little underpowered for advanced users however; it will still do the trick;)

We have 1.3 128x64 SSD1306 OLED Display on board. The way we connect the display to the board is unique. Usually, OLED displays are soldered on PCB, there is nothing wrong about this, however; OLED displays can be very fragile if you don’t protect them. Once you break the display unsolder-solder process is very painful. We used flat flex connector(FFC) type OLED display. If you broke the display you can simply pop up the connector hand and change the OLED. Another advantage of FFC connector type OLED is you can take off the display and use the board for applications that don’t require a display in a harsh environment.

The battery does not require soldering! We used a very slim connector to connect the battery to the board, this will allow you to change the battery once your battery dies or when you want to use a higher capacity battery. When you are not using the watch you can also disconnect the battery to store the watch safely.

We have 3 tactile switches. You can use these switches for navigating at watch menu. Switches will be handy on your own development as well.

We have two general purpose green LEDs under the display.

watchX packed with many features and sensors. It’s really very hard to describe every feature of it. It’s totally different to experience watchX in real life instead of reading the specs. We hope you will love it.

Housing

watchX does not include any housing because:

It’s freaking cool to have a PCB in watch style.

It will force you to learn 3D design. Remember as humans we only learn something if we need it! You will need a housing for watchX sooner or later. Then you will download the 3D design, you will be amused that 3D design includes everything that exists on the real product. Then you will go to the good old friend GOOGLE and type 3D design, for finishing out how to import a STEP file, how to draw something on 3D model etc. Then you will get familiar with the industrial design.

watchX can be used as something else other than watch. You can set an alarm ( or trigger) to water the plants on certain days of the week. Or you can use it as an outdoor weather station. All these applications require different housing designs. We will give you the 3D model of watchX. There will be everything on the 3D model that you will see on watchX itself(including resistors and capacitors). You won’t need any measurement to draw the case you need for your application. We will also provide you different housing designs ready to download. Then you can print these housings with a 3D printer.

 

Options of watchX

*Regardless of which one you pick, you can use the one you like after purchase.

 

If I back, what do I get?

 

 

Stretch Goals

 

 

Why we are in INDIEGOGO

We are a group of engineers who left their job and put their time and money to develop watchX. We are covering all the expenses of watchX from our savings. We believe that we did well till this point. To move forward we need more money than we can cover. This is where we need you and IndieGoGo. If we can receive enough money from our campaign, we will cover expenses like:

- Component sourcing
- Printed Circuit Board(PCB) Manufacturing
- PCB Assembly
- Boxing of watchX
- Certification and Licensing

Also, we need a certain number of orders because some components we use require a minimum order quantity limit. We hope you back us on overcoming these problems.

Our Road Map After Funding

*Manuf. = Manufacturing

Your contribution is very important for the success of our campaign.

              


 

About the Team

We are a team of engineers, designers and creative people who enjoy to design and develop hardware that touches people’s lives. Before we started developing watchX, me (Mustafa), Enes and Omer, were working at a medical R&D company that manufactures fully implantable medical pacemakers. I (Mustafa) was Lead Engineer who was in charge of managing the operation from concept to manufacturing. Enes was design engineer who had to overcome delicate topics like waterproofness and body compatible industrial design and Omer was responsible for the manufacturing of PCBs without any problem.  We gained most of our expertise in electronics, industrial design and PCB manufacturing during 2 years of hard work and study. Our team got even powerful with Gokhan and Harun who are very talented engineers as well.

 

Mustafa TULU

Co-founder of argeX, Embedded system designer of watchX. Worked for confidential military projects, research facilities and PCB manufacturing related projects. Enjoys fitness, aviation and nature.

Expecting a baby in three months:)

 

Enes CALDIR

Co-founder of argeX, He is responsible for all design related topics of watchX, he prepared very cool reference housing designs for watchX. Stay tuned! He loves bikes and cats. He currently drives MT-07. His cat’s name is Merlion. We named her after our visit to Singapore :)

 

Zak Kemble

Zak is a highly talented embedded software engineer. He is the developer of piece of art watchX watch UI firmware. He enjoys DIY electronics projects and exploring outdoors.

 

 

Omer OZLU

Responsible for problem free manufacturing of watchX, has excellent social relations. Passionate about mountain climbing, He climbed Mountain Kazbek, Suphan, Erciyes, Demirkazik. His next destination is Elbrus Russia.

 

Gokhan SELAMET

Software guy, he is responsible for future improvements of watchX firmware. Loves music, he is a skilled drum player. He is planning to invent his own electronic drum one day.

 

 

Harun BASKAYA

Harun is responsible for all the media related things of watchX, he is passionate about photography. We are thrilled to have him on board.

 

 

 

Risks and Challenges

There are always challenges in mass production. We have to make sure our products will be secure and reliable and they can be manufactured efficiently at large volumes.

Thankfully, we have strong experience in PCB design and manufacturing process from our ex-work. We still keep in touch with people whom we supplied electronic components and bare PCBs. We also established very good relations with manufacturers in Shenzhen/China. Moreover, watchX does not require the same tooling cost and manufacturing risks as products with injection molded plastic require.

Of course, there are risks involved with the manufacturing of watchX. Unexpected changes in component lead times or availability are examples of factors that can affect delivery time line. We are doing our best to minimize these risks and deliver watchX right on time.

The other risk with our product or any other product is shipping. There are a number of unforeseen incidents that can cause problems during shipping of watchX. We plan to work with proven companies that will carry watchX safe and sound to your doorstep.

You won’t need any measurement to draw the case you need for your application. We will also provide you different housing designs ready to download. Then you can print these housings with a 3D printer. Options of watchX*Regardless of which one you pick, you can use the one you like after purchase. If I back, what do I get?  Stretch Goals  Why we are in INDIEGOGOWe are a group of engineers who left their job and put their time and money to develop watchX. We are covering all the expenses of watchX from our savings. We believe that we did well till this point. To move forward we need more money than we can cover. This is where we need you and IndieGoGo. If we can receive enough money from our campaign, we will cover expenses like:- Component sourcing- Printed Circuit Board(PCB) Manufacturing- PCB Assembly- Boxing of watchX- Certification and LicensingAlso, we need a certain number of orders because some components we use require a minimum order quantity limit. We hope you back us on overcoming these problems.Our Road Map After Funding*Manuf. = ManufacturingYour contribution is very important for the success of our campaign.                About the TeamWe are a team of engineers, designers and creative people who enjoy to design and develop hardware that touches people’s lives. Before we started developing watchX, me (Mustafa), Enes and Omer, were working at a medical R&D company that manufactures fully implantable medical pacemakers. I (Mustafa) was Lead Engineer who was in charge of managing the operation from concept to manufacturing. Enes was design engineer who had to overcome delicate topics like waterproofness and body compatible industrial design and Omer was responsible for the manufacturing of PCBs without any problem.  We gained most of our expertise in electronics, industrial design and PCB manufacturing during 2 years of hard work and study. Our team got even powerful with Gokhan and Harun who are very talented engineers as well. Mustafa TULUCo-founder of argeX, Embedded system designer of watchX. Worked for confidential military projects, research facilities and PCB manufacturing related projects. Enjoys fitness, aviation and nature.Expecting a baby in three months:) Enes CALDIRCo-founder of argeX, He is responsible for all design related topics of watchX, he prepared very cool reference housing designs for watchX. Stay tuned! He loves bikes and cats. He currently drives MT-07. His cat’s name is Merlion. We named her after our visit to Singapore :) Zak KembleZak is a highly talented embedded software engineer. He is the developer of piece of art watchX watch UI firmware. He enjoys DIY electronics projects and exploring outdoors.  Omer OZLUResponsible for problem free manufacturing of watchX, has excellent social relations. Passionate about mountain climbing, He climbed Mountain Kazbek, Suphan, Erciyes, Demirkazik. His next destination is Elbrus Russia. Gokhan SELAMETSoftware guy, he is responsible for future improvements of watchX firmware. Loves music, he is a skilled drum player. He is planning to invent his own electronic drum one day.  Harun BASKAYAHarun is responsible for all the media related things of watchX, he is passionate about photography. We are thrilled to have him on board.   Risks and ChallengesThere are always challenges in mass production. We have to make sure our products will be secure and reliable and they can be manufactured efficiently at large volumes.Thankfully, we have strong experience in PCB design and manufacturing process from our ex-work. We still keep in touch with people whom we supplied electronic components and bare PCBs. We also established very good relations with manufacturers in Shenzhen/China. Moreover, watchX does not require the same tooling cost and manufacturing risks as products with injection molded plastic require.Of course, there are risks involved with the manufacturing of watchX. Unexpected changes in component lead times or availability are examples of factors that can affect delivery time line. We are doing our best to minimize these risks and deliver watchX right on time.The other risk with our product or any other product is shipping. There are a number of unforeseen incidents that can cause problems during shipping of watchX. We plan to work with proven companies that will carry watchX safe and sound to your doorstep.

story:
The Shlocker is the first solution for people who would like to leave their personal care products in the shower, yet don’t want to leave their items vulnerable to use or tampering by housemates, roommates, or siblings.

Great for:

  • Siblings sharing a bathroom
  • College Dorms, Suites + Apartments
  • Gyms
  • Sorority + Fraternity Houses
  • Parents with young children who want to limit access to certain items

Essentially a shower locker, the Shlocker allows you to store your items securely in the space they were meant to stay in while it eliminates the need to lug things back and forth each time you shower.

Born out of a need

After years of sharing bathrooms with siblings, college roommates, and then apartment roommates post-grad, we grew frustrated with the notion that the portable shower caddy was the only available means of keeping our personal care products for ourselves.

We chose to bridge the gap between security and convenience

Over a year from inception of the idea, our small, independent team has put countless hours and effort as well as a good amount of personal funds into the design and development of the Shlocker.

By backing this project, you’ll help provide the funds needed for tooling and first order with our manufacturer, while taking advantage of special value & special edition rewards!

Shlock it up!

The Shlocker is designed to be simple. It’s constructed of a durable, non-toxic, BPA-Free plastic and features an easy-to-use, waterproof, 3-number, combination lock.

Holes have been added for drainage and air circulation, but are small enough to not compromise the security of the contents.

On the Inside

Designed to fit seamlessly into the existing space, the Shlocker is unobtrusive once installed in the shower. Don’t let the sleek exterior deceive you: the inside of the Shlocker has plenty of space and can hold multiple jumbo-sized products.

Inside each Shlocker is a removable shelf with drainage as well as four larger holes designated for storing razors/toothbrushes/etc. An anti-fog mirror is included on the inside of the door.

Two commercial-grade, twist ’n lock suction cups are included for maximum strength and support. Each suction cup is capable of holding 44 pounds of weight. 

The suction cups work on virtually any flat, dry, non-porous surface. Four holes on the back of the Shlocker allow for versatile installation in the case of grout lines.


How we're going to do it

Once funded, we'll immediately commence the tooling process which is expected to take 45 days. Upon approved inspection of the first run, we'll place the first order! Manufacturing and shipping will take up to two months. Once our fulfillment center receives the first order, your Shlocker will be on it's way to you!

Challenges + Risks

While we've got a solid action plan in place, we are also aware that unforeseen challenges can happen. Below, we have detailed potential hiccups.

TOOLING & MANUFACTURING: We have worked hand-in-hand with our manufacturer on the design and prototyping and are confident that we have the right partner. Any delays in this arena are likely to be minimal, and we will keep backers posted if and when they arise.

FULFILLMENT: We've researched common missteps that happen when trying to fulfill large reward shipments generated from super-successful campaigns. So as not to run into this issue, we've confirmed our manufacturer's maximum output capabilities and have a strong understanding of their lead times.

SHIPPING: We have zeroed in on quotes from logistic centers to help ship the Shlockers. The companies we've scoped out are very capable of handling and shipping both domestically and internationally.

We've put a great amount of time, personal capital, and passion into the Shlocker. We're committed to making this available to the world. Whether with good news or setbacks, we will keep you in the loop and will do everything in our power to get you your Shlocker on schedule!

story:
Ray LeGrande Sr. is a Certified WASP II Pilot.

Our goal is to produce the WR35 Airframe and the WR19-7 Fanjet engine with modern engineering that is 30 years more advanced than 1982.

Scott Watson: is a designer of mechanical and electrical transportation systems, always pushing the limits of technology in new and unusual ways, Being able to see the connections between applications and building the Widget that makes all the various technologies work is his specialty.

The machine shops and 3D printing services assist in creating low cost plastic prototypes of the engine which is allowing mechanical issues to be resolved prior to production of the aluminum and titanium engine components.

Efficiency is the goal and this is being achieved with due diligence and attention to detail.

Sam Williams (deceased) was the original designer of the WASP II concept, the US ARMY declined to accept the radical design, some people said it would not get off the ground or it would crash.

The WASP II worked as designed and it never crashed, One person said the regular Pilots saw the WASP II as a threat to their flight pay.

Due to the advances in manufacturing ability, We are currently manufacturing parts in the Seattle area machine shops, The original WASP II is on display at, The Museum of Flight located in Seattle Washington, We have the technical manuals and the ability to build the parts and assemble them.

In closing, thirty years have passed since Ray LeGrande Sr. flew the WASP II, We are building four and giving him the chance to teach us how to fly.

If you want to read the original newspaper articles from the public display presented by the US ARMY at Fort Benning GA, Here is the link to the archives, Scott Watson contacted the Bayonet Newspaper and requested the 1982 archives be updated and posted on line.

http://www.benning.army.mil/library/content/Virtual/Bayonet/index.htm
First Article
June 11, 1982
Go to Volume 40
Number 38
Page one
then go to page 26.

Second Article
June 18, 1982
Volume 40.
Number 39.
Page one.

Popular Science wrote a concise article about the WASP II which is located on page 67 of this link:

http://books.google.com/books…

We have the technology, The will and the time, We are building the 2012 WASP at this time, The campaign is:

"I WANT ONE".

Respectfully, Ray LeGrande Sr. and Scott Watson

Websites

  • http://youtube.com
  • http://popularmechanics.com
  • http://books.google.com
  • http://youtube.com
  • http://youtube.com
  • http://youtube.com
  • http://amazon.com
  • http://benning.army.mil
  • http://museumofflight.org

  • The pipe bending service said we are building Iron Man Tech.

"Freedom is to take off from your driveway and fly wherever you want.         

No more traffic jams"

We are in the process of converting the 2D blueprints into a 3D CAD file for the purpose of developing parts using the latest in 3D printing, which will allow us to fabricate parts to build a complete airframe and engine.

Terry L. Metzgar has pointed out the need for developing a more streamlined fairing which will provide more efficient aerodynamics for greater range and a higher top speed.

A 5 AXIS mill reduces the cost of manufacturing the engine components by 30% over the traditional machine shop, Due to the engine being 26 inches long and 14 inches in diameter the materials are not the major expense, It is the 166 hours of machine time that are required to machine the parts.

The CAD programming allows a level of precision and speed which reduces the cost and man hours to produce each part.

We know that the WASP II works and is simple to use, Someone said,

"Give it to the people and see what they do with it"

So what would you do with a vertical take off and landing WASP?

We are building them, You tell us what it is good for, I think it would make a nice camera platform for use in the production of Hollywood films or delivering Red Cross medications to remote locations, For the price of one helicopter fourteen WASP units can be built, They require 3 hours of training to fly.

We have the technology and the blueprints

"I WANT ONE" is the campaign.

Enjoy watching the video and slide show.People in the past have wondered why a major corporation did not develop this WASP II (We still don't know).

The landing on Mars using a vertical thrust platform which delivered a 1 ton = 2200 pounds Mars rover, Proves we have the technology to build the WASP II and it was done in 1974, Imagine what 30 years of jet engine technology will allow us to achieve now. I know 40% increase in thrust is possible because this has already happened.

The risk to the pilots is minimal due to the parachute which is located in the nose of the WASP II, 3 hours of training is required for basic operations.

Sincerely, Ray LeGrande Sr and Scott Watson.

story:
zur deutschen Version scrollen

At a glance - Seeing like a young person again

The eye. It is our most important sensory organ.

Wouldn't it be great to see perfectly sharply from near to far like a young person again without the annoying glasses.

By the age of 50, everyone is suffering from presbyopia. Opacification of the lens – cataracts – are even worse: one in two people over 60 gets them, and a further one in two of these are operated on. There are still no satisfactory solutions to restore natural, healthy eyesight.

This is exactly what we are working on: the new bio-inspired intraocular lens „DeepSight“ by biolnic should soon enable sharp near vision and far vision. DeepSight imitates the incredible softness and elasticity of a healthy, natural lens and also deforms just like one. It's like inventing the fountain of youth for your eyes.

We have a highly promising solution for the problems of presbyopia and cataracts – DeepSight must be developed to a marketable stage and a first clinical trial on humans must be carried out. This will take about 2,5 years. For this we need you!

Make something unique possible: purchase a transferable option on a pair of DeepSight lenses now with a 20%, 40% or 90% discount on the intended market price of $5,000 (4,000€), which you can redeem after achieving marketability. Or we will pass every of your donations to charitable foundations who help prevent blindness, and in addition, we will donate a pair of DeepSight every time biolnic raises $500 via your donations, if the project will succeed.

We get 80% of our impressions from healthy eyes. We are working meticulously on significantly improving our quality of life in old age with DeepSight so that we can live more actively. Please support us in doing so, here or soon on biolnic.com.

Content

  • A little bit of medicine first of all

  • How DeepSight works

  • What will make DeepSight unique

  • Who is behind DeepSight

  • The work we do

  • Our awesome partners

  • Challenges to be mastered

  • Let’s go, we need you! (Perks)

  • News

  • Synopsis

  • FAQ

Top

A little bit of medicine first of all

The natural lens

The lens of the human eye is a crystal-clear, extremely elastic body which bundles the light that enters via the pupil onto the retina to create a sharp picture. It is embedded in a wafer-thin “capsular sac” which is attached to the ring-formed ciliary muscle by zonula fibers, which radiate laterally into the equator of the capsule.

Cataracts and presbyopia

A particularly serious and slowly progressive disease is cataracts, in which the lenses of the eye become opaque, resulting in increased glare sensitivity of the eye and faded perception of colors. Advanced cataracts can only be treated through surgery to replace the natural lens with an artificial intraocular lens (IOL) after opening of the capsular sac.

Presbyopia is the age-related loss of the adaptability of the eye to different object distances (accommodation). This is essentially based on the loss of elasticity in the lens core. This is normally corrected using one or more pairs of glasses.

Accommodation

In accommodation - the focusing of the eye - the ring-shaped muscle (“ciliar”) does not exert any force on the lens as you would assume. Instead, the zonula fibers relax in the event of contraction of the ciliary muscle and the lens switches into its natural spherical shape for near vision. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) examinations show that the changes in diameter during accommodation of the ciliary muscle are only slightly different for young people and old people, at approximately 0.6 mm.

Conventional IOLs

Standard intraocular lenses (IOLs) have only one focus and provide either near or far vision.

There are also bifocal or multifocal lenses with more than one focus which are not completely rigid like the standard IOLs but, however, are unable to accommodate and to change their shape. The disadvantage of multifocal lenses is the significantly worse contrast vision and increased glare sensitivity (particularly at night). In a similar manner to varifocal glasses, the field of vision is narrower which results in a non-physiological rocking of the head.

Complications of IOLs

The most frequent complication arising from the use of intraocular lenses is the opacification of the posterior capsule (post-cataract occurrences). This requires additional laser surgery.

Accommodable IOLs

Contrary to what is widely assumed, the accommodation of the eye is not yet able to be returned to a satisfactory state. Only refractive power changes of about 1.5 diopter can be achieved, but at least 3 diopter are needed for near and far vision.

There is a lack of sophisticated biomechanical solutions in which the function of focusing imitates the nature function as closely as possible. And this needs to be without the eye or brain having to shift, without (optical) mistakes and without electronic aids!

Another shortcoming: the capsular sac “damaged” by opening can compress a flexible IOL into its flat condition for far vision only to a very limited extent.

Setting new standards

The power transmission that is behind construction and design of the DeepSight is much more efficient.
In this, the IOL is to be connected to the ciliary muscle directly.

Content

How “DeepSight” works

Looking into nature’s soul

How it should work

The lens-shaped DeepSight is flat in its distance condition, just like its natural model. It consists of a thin, extremely elastic shell and a liquid, highly refractive core. The ciliary muscle nestles itself around the “haptic ring”, the edge of the IOL. This one can follow the contraction of the ciliary muscle due to the thin slits. The DeepSight get rounder: near objects become sharp!


Our simulations (optical as well as stress and deformation analyses) show that with the bio-inspired DeepSight a multiple of refractive power change than the necessary 3 diopter for near to distant vision can be achieved already with less than a half diameter change of the ciliar. This has still to be proven in the clinical trial.


How DeepSight should be implanted

The DeepSight should be implanted in a similarly uncomplicated way like conventional IOLs, which can be performed in as little as 10 minutes. For implantation, the capsular sac is removed or shifted behind the intraocular lens. The DeepSight is inserted into the ciliary muscle. In addition it can be fixed to the ciliary muscle or eyeball. During implantation, the lens is pressed flat so the filling is transferred to a connected tube which is rolled up into a small shape.

Content

What will make DeepSight unique

DeepSight stands out in all of its details by the simplicity of the design in the form of a bio-inspired system which is very close to human physiology. The change in shape of the IOL as an indicator for the accommodation capacity is even much higher than that of the natural lens ie from an almost flat far vision state to a highly curved near vision state.

These unique selling propositions are our objective

  • Natural, sharp vision from approximately 25 cm to a distance without further visual aids, restriction of the visual field and an adjustment of the eye or brain.
  • DeepSight aims to make the most possible use of the muscle contraction by being fully enclosed by the ciliary muscle and by being extremely deformable due to the slits in the haptic ring and liquid core.
  • The very large optics provides significantly improved night vision.
  • The post-cataract occurrences or a decentration are far less likely.
  • It also aims to help patients suffering from very poor vision.
  • Lower costs in the long term compared to other visual aids.
  • Patients with conventional IOLs can replace them with DeepSight.

Content

Who is behind DeepSight

We’re a team of biomedical and scientific experts who get their kicks from using tech to make people fall in love with our lenses

We, Andreas, Ben and Josef know each other from the COTECH Project supported by the European Union (www.fp7-cotech.eu).

Dr. Josef Jansen is the founder of biolnic and head of DeepSight. As a mechanical engineer (having written his dissertation/PhD on artificial heart valves), for the last 30 years he has been working on the development of implants for the human body which imitate nature. His core skill is the analysis and understanding of the mechanism of action of body parts which are put under a large amount of stress and their technical and constructive implementation in a physiological biomechanical design with elasticity close to that found in nature. Josef combines the highest technical requirements with the simplicity of natural solutions. Visionary and innovative product development is his passion. And this frequently comes from small, innovative companies which often achieve more skill, flexibility and continuity in this special field.

Dr. Andreas Schoth is physicist and engineer and a scientific expert in the field of microsystem technology. He has been working in this innovative field since he wrote his dissertation (PhD) on quantum mechanical silicon sensors in 1995. Freely adapted from Richard Feynman’s "There is Plenty of Room at the Bottom", Andreas researches and develops manufacturing technologies for different applications; from “lab on the chip” to highly miniaturized implants. This also includes, for example, micro and nano injection molding of smart materials.

Dr. Ben Whiteside has been pushing the boundaries of ultra-high precision injection molding since 2001. His background includes a PhD study of the mechanical properties of polymer composite materials and over ten years as a researcher and lecturer studying computer modelling of polymer processes, process data acquisition of polymer manufacturing systems, high speed imaging and visualization technique development and manufacturing of polymer components with micro and nano-scale precision. Ben is now Director of the Centre for Micro and Nano Molding at the University of Bradford, which is a unique facility worldwide for the manufacture of nano-precision devices using a wide range of materials.

Content

The work we do

We go to painstaking lengths to ensure that no stone is left unturned in our quest for the best way forward to an accommodative IOL

Where we stand

The design of the IOL was developed for attachment to the ciliary muscle. We have therefore already been through a long process in which numerous designs of the DeepSight were simulated using complex calculation programs. In addition, it was also possible to manufacture a prototype of an extremely complex shaped IOL intended for implantation in the capsular sac using state-of-the-art micro technologies – with a partner from Bradford in the European COTECH Project (www.fp7-cotech.eu).

What has to be done

A great deal of work is still in front of us. The micro precision manufacturing technology and the design of DeepSight are further optimized in terms of the plastics used and tailored to one another. Various different examinations and tests are being carried out. Initial pre-production models of the DeepSight are being examined in a clinical pilot investigation with 10 patients in which accommodation ability of the IOL is being demonstrated over a period of six months (until mid-2017). Therefore biolnic needs approximately $2.1 (1.7€) million. And that’s why we need you!

The subsequent, extensive clinical trial with approximately 400 patients should last for around two years. In parallel, automated series production will be established. This can be covered by EU financing programs. Marketability of the DeepSight lens as medical product for the European region should then be achieved and the sale by industry partners can begin.

Series production – quality knows no compromises

The series production of DeepSight is likely to be carried out by biolnic itself and built up together with the partners.

This is because the highest possible quality standards are always at the forefront!

Content

Our awesome partners

Close cooperation with excellent partners enables us to do world-class work

For the micro production technologies, biolnic is cooperating with competent partners from the COTECH EU project.

The COTECH project

biolnic is continuing the developments in accommodable intraocular lenses made by the company be innovative on the basis of the COTECH (2008-2012: „Converging technologies for micro systems manufacturing“, www.fp7-cotech.eu) project supported by the European Union. Completely new micro production technologies were developed by 25 European partners in COTECH. The “demonstrator” created by be innovative was an accommodable IOL which can be implanted in the capsular sac with deformable optics. The IOL was made of two differently shaped, aspherical half shells which were then assembled.

The Centre for Polymer Micro and Nano Technology at the University of Bradford (UK) has been internationally recognized for its pioneering research in the field of micro injection molding since 2001. It has an extensive range of cutting edge processing hardware specifically designed for the industrial-scale manufacture of micro and nano precision components. They have developed bespoke systems for monitoring the behavior of the raw material and the equipment dynamics in production processes. Further novel sensor technologies and data acquisition systems enable full traceability of the production environment for product manufacture – particularly relevant for the medical device sector. In addition, the Centre has a dedicated characterization laboratory (e.g. for assessing the shape and mechanical properties of micro injection molded components and surface features). A highly skilled team provides the expertise for developing new processes and technologies to overcome the significant challenges required for the manufacture of state-of-the-art devices.


The Department of Microsystems Engineering (IMTEK) at the University of Freiburg (Germany) is an internationally leading institute in the field of life sciences, brain computers interface and micro/nanotechnology. IMTEK has detailed knowledge and experience in the field of plastic molding with sub micrometer precision and in the production of high-precision injection molded shapes and embossing dies with optical surfaces.


The Department of Experimental Ophthalmology (Prof. Dr. rer. nat. Dr. med. Solon Thanos) is a recognized research institution at the University of Münster (Germany). The working group dominates the field of clinical and experimental ophthalmology, biocompatibility studies, in vitro cultures of nerve, lens and corneal cells are routinely carried out.

Content

Challenges to be mastered

Great ideas need robust strategies to turn them into reality

Needless to say, many medical technology risks and challenges arise during the development of new implants for the human body:

  • The micro injection molding of highly elastic precision components and thus production of DeepSight are extremely demanding but can be realized with our competent partners from the COTECH project.
  • The accommodation of DeepSight must be adequately shown within the scope of the clinical trials on humans.
  • Furthermore, the precise selection of the correct size of IOL for the ciliary muscle depends on the care of the physician and suitable imaging procedures. Ophthalmologists, however, are used to precision and care.
  • Generally, the long-term behavior of implants cannot be assessed 100% reliably in advance. But it should be the same as for the conventional IOL.

It certainly should also be pointed out here that it is possible that in such projects development steps, tests or even clinical trials may need to be repeated. This can result in the failure of the enterprise in the worst case due to not reaching marketability of the lenses as a medical product and therefore a loss of the option. We are certainly going to do our best to ensure that this does not happen, but we are not able to rule out such a worst case scenario entirely.

Zum Anfang

Ein bisschen Medizin zuerst

Die natürliche Linse

Die Linse des menschlichen Auges ist ein kristallklarer, extrem elastischer Körper, der das durch die Pupille eintretende Licht auf der Netzhaut in ein scharfes Bild bündelt. Sie ist in einem hauchdünnen „Kapselsack“ gelagert, welcher über seitlich in den Äquator der Kapsel einstrahlende Zonula- fasern am ringförmigen Ziliarmuskel aufgehängt ist.

Der Graue Star und die Alterssichtigkeit

Eine besonders gravierende und langsam fortschreitende Erkrankung ist der Graue Star („Katarakt“), bei der es zur Trübung der Augenlinse kommt. Die Folgen sind eine erhöhte Blendempfindlichkeit des Auges und die verblasste Wahrnehmung von Farben. Der fortgeschrittene Graue Star kann nur operativ behandelt werden, indem die natürliche Linse nach Öffnung des Kapselsacks durch eine - künstliche - Intraokularlinse (IOL) ausgetauscht wird.

Die Alterssichtigkeit („Presbyopie“) ist der altersbedingte Verlust der Anpassungsfähigkeit des Auges an unterschiedliche Gegenstandsweiten (Akkommodation). Im Wesentlichen beruht dies auf einem Elastizitätsverlust des Linsenkerns. Die Korrektur erfolgt in der Regel mit einer oder mehreren Brillen.

Die Akkommodation

Bei der Akkommodation, dem Scharfstellen des Auges, übt der ringförmige Muskel („Ziliar“) nicht, wie man annehmen könnte, eine Kraft auf die Linse aus. Stattdessen entspannen sich bei Kontraktion des Ziliar die Zonulafasern und die Linse stellt sich in ihre kugelige Eigenform für die Nahsicht zurück. Magnetresonanztomographie (MRT)-Untersuchungen zeigen, dass die Durchmesseränderung des Ziliar bei der Akkommodation sich nur relativ geringfügig zwischen jung zu alt unterscheidet und bei etwa 0,6mm liegt.

Herkömmliche IOL’s

Standard Intraokularlinsen (IOL’s) haben nur einen Fokus, womit man entweder nur nah oder fern sehen kann.

Daneben gibt es Bifokal- bzw. Multifokallinsen mit mehreren Fokussen, die zwar wie die Standard IOL’s nicht völlig starr sind, jedoch nicht akkommodieren und ihre Form verändern können. Der Nachteil der Multifokallinsen liegt in dem deutlich schlechteren Kontrastsehvermögen und erhöhter Blendempfindlichkeit (insbesondere bei Nacht). Ähnlich wie bei Gleitsichtbrillen ist zudem der Sehbereich kleiner, welches ein unphysiologisches Schaukeln des Kopfes nach sich zieht.

Komplikationen von IOL’s

Die häufigste Komplikation bei der Verwendung von Intraokularlinsen ist die Eintrübung der Hinterkapsel, der „Nachstar“. Dieser erfordert einen zusätzlichen operativen Eingriff mittels eines Lasers.

Akkommodierbare IOL’s

Anders als vielfach angenommen kann die Akkommodation des Auges bislang nicht zufriedenstellend wiederhergestellt werden! Es werden nur Brechkraftänderungen von etwa 1,5 Dioptrien erreicht; für die Nah- bis Fernsicht sind jedoch mindestens 3 Dioptrien nötig.

Durchdachte biomechanische Lösungen fehlen, bei denen die Funktion des Scharfstellens möglichst exakt der Natur nachgeahmt wird. Und zwar ohne dass sich Auge oder Gehirn umstellen müssten oder es zu (optischen) Fehlleistungen kommen könnte und ohne elektronische Hilfsmittel!

Weiteres Manko: Der durch die Öffnung „beschädigte“ Kapselsack kann eine flexible IOL nur sehr eingeschränkt in ihren flachen Zustand für die Fernsicht zusammendrücken.

Neue Standards setzen

Viel effizienter ist die Kraftübertragung, die hinter der Konstruktion und dem Design der DeepSight steckt! Hier soll die IOL direkt an den Ziliarmuskel angekoppelt werden.

Inhaltsverzeichnis


Wie die „DeepSight“ funktioniert

Der Natur in die Seele geschaut

Wie sie funktionieren soll

Die linsenförmige DeepSight ist wie ihr natürliches Vorbild im Fernzustand flach. Sie besteht aus einer dünnen, äußerst elastischen Schale mit einem flüssigen, hoch-lichtbrechenden Kern. Der Ziliarmuskel schmiegt sich um den „Haptikring“, den Rand der IOL. Dieser kann aufgrund der dünnen Schlitze der Kontraktion des Ziliar folgen. Die DeepSight wird runder: nahe Objekte werden scharf abgebildet!

Unsere Simulationen (optische sowie Spannungs- und Verformungsanalysen) zeigen, dass mit der bioinspirierten DeepSight schon bei weniger als der halben Durchmesseränderung des Ziliar von nur 0,2mm ein mehrfaches an Brechkraftänderung als der benötigten 3 Dioptrien für Nah- bis Fernsicht erzielt werden könnte. Dies soll in der klinischen Prüfung belegt werden.

Wie die DeepSight implantiert werden soll

Die DeepSight soll sich ähnlich unkompliziert implantieren lassen wie herkömmliche IOL’s, wobei dies nur etwa 10 min. dauert. Zur Implantation wird der Kapselsack entfernt oder hinter die Intraokularlinse verschoben. Die DeepSight wird in den Ziliarmuskel eingesetzt. Sie kann zudem am Ziliar oder dem Augapfel befestigt werden. Für den Implantationsvorgang wird die Linse flach gedrückt, die Füllung dadurch in einen angekoppelten Schlauch überführt und klein aufgerollt.

Inhaltsverzeichnis

Was die DeepSight einzigartig machen soll

Die DeepSight besticht in der Summe der Details durch die Einfachheit des Designs in Form eines bioinspirierten Systems, welches der menschlichen Physiologie sehr nahekommt. Die Form der IOL verändert sich - als Maß für die Brechkraftänderung - sogar deutlich stärker als die der natürlichen Linse, von einem nahezu ebenen Fernzustand in einen sehr stark gekrümmten Nahzustand.

Diese Alleinstellungsmerkmale sind unser Ziel

  • Natürliches, scharfes Sehen von 25 cm bis Fern ohne zusätzliche Sehhilfen, Gesichtsfeldeinschränkung und Umstellung von Auge oder Gehirn.
  • Die DeepSight soll die Muskelkontraktion maximal ausnutzen, indem sie vollständig vom Ziliar umschlossen wird und durch die Schlitze im Haptikring und dem flüssigen Kern äußerst verformbar ist.
  • Die sehr große Optik ermöglicht ein signifikant besseres Nachtsichtverhalten.
  • Der Nachstar oder eine Dezentrierung sind weit weniger wahrscheinlich.
  • Sie soll auch Patienten mit starker Fehlsichtigkeit helfen.
  • Langfristig niedrigere Kosten im Vergleich zu sonstigen Sehhilfen.
  • Patienten mit konventioneller IOL können sich diese durch eine DeepSight ersetzen lassen.

Wer hinter DeepSight steht

Wir sind ein Team aus biomedizinischen und wissenschaftlichen Experten, deren Kick darin liegt, Technologien zu nutzen, dass Menschen sich in unsere Linsen verlieben

Wir, Andreas, Ben und Josef kennen uns aus dem von der Europäischen Union geförderten Projekt COTECH (www.fp7-cotech.eu).

Dr. Josef Jansen ist der Gründer der biolnic und Kopf der DeepSight. Als Maschinenbau- ingenieur (Dissertation über künstliche Herzklappen) beschäftigt er sich seit 30 Jahren mit der Entwicklung von der Natur nachgeahmten Implantaten für den menschlichen Körper. Seine Kernkompetenz liegt in der Analyse und dem Verständnis der Wirkungsweise von hochbeanspruchten Körperteilen und deren technisch-konstruktiver Umsetzung in ein physiologiegerechtes, biomechanisches Design mit naturnaher Elastizität. Josef verbindet höchste technische Ansprüche mit der Einfachheit von Lösungen aus der Natur. Visionäre und innovative Produktentwicklungen sind seine Leidenschaft. Und diese kommen häufig aus kleinen, innovativen Unternehmen, die in diesem Spezialbereich oft mehr Kompetenz, Flexibilität und Kontinuität gewährleisten.

Dr. Andreas Schoth ist Physiker und Ingenieur und der wissenschaftliche Experte auf dem Gebiet der Mikrosystemtechnik. Er ist seit seiner Dissertation über quantenmechanische Siliziumsensoren im Jahre 1995 in diesem innovativen Gebiet zu Hause. Frei nach Richard Feynmans "There is Plenty of Room at the Bottom" (Ganz unten ist eine Menge Platz), erforscht und entwickelt Andreas Fertigungstechnologien für unterschiedliche Anwendungen; vom „Lab on the Chip“ zu hochminiaturisierten Implantaten. Dazu gehört auch als ein Beispiel, dass Mikro-und Nanospritzgiessen von smarten Materialien.

Dr. Ben Whiteside überwindet seit 2001 immer wieder die Grenzen des Ultrapräzisionsspritzgusses. Die mechanischen Eigenschaften von Polymerverbundstoffen war Thema seiner Dissertation. Danach beschäftigte er sich über zehn Jahre als Forscher und Dozent mit Computermodellierungen von Polymerprozessen, Prozessdatenerfassung von Polymerfertigungssystemen, Hochgeschwindigkeitsbilderfassung und der Entwicklung von Visualisierungstechnik ebenso wie mit der Fertigung von Polymerkomponenten im Mikro- und Nanobereich. Zurzeit ist Ben Direktor am Centre for Micro and Nano Moulding an der Universität Bradford, das sich als weltweit einzigartige Einrichtung mit der Fertigung von Nanopräzisionsinstrumenten aus einer breiten Materialpalette beschäftigt.

Inhaltsverzeichnis

Arbeit die wir machen

Wir scheuen keine Mühen, um sicher zu stellen, dass nichts unversucht bleibt auf unserer Suche nach dem besten Weg für eine akkommodative IOL

Wo wir stehen

Das Design der IOL wurde für die Ankoppelung an den Ziliarmuskel entwickelt. Hierbei sind wir bereits durch einen langen Prozess gegangen, in dem vielzählige Designs der DeepSight mit aufwendigen Berechnungsprogrammen simuliert wurden. Zudem konnte ein Prototyp einer für die Implantation in den Kapselsack vorgesehenen, äußerst komplex geformten IOL mit modernsten Mikrotechnologien gefertigt werden - mit einem Partner aus Bradford in dem europäischen Projekt COTECH (www.fp7-cotech.eu).

Was zu tun ist

Viel Arbeit steht noch vor uns. Die Mikropräzisionsfertigungs- technik sowie das Design der DeepSight werden hinsichtlich des Kunststoffs weiter optimiert und aufeinander abgestimmt. Verschiedenste Prüfungen und Tests werden durchgeführt. Erste Vorserienmodelle der DeepSight werden dann in einer „klinischen Pilotstudie“ an 10 Patienten untersucht, in der die Akkommodationsfähigkeit der IOL über ein halbes Jahr aufgezeigt wird (bis Mitte 2017). Hierfür benötigt biolnic rund $2.1 Mio. (1,7€ Mio.). Und dafür brauchen wir Sie!

Die anschließende, umfassende klinische Prüfung an etwa 400 Patienten soll rund 2 Jahre dauern. Parallel wird die automatisierte Serienfertigung aufgebaut. Dies kann über Finanzierungsprogramme der EU gedeckt werden. Danach soll die „Verkehrsfähigkeit“ der DeepSight Linse als Medizinprodukt in der Europäischen Union erreicht werden und der Verkauf über Partner aus der Industrie beginnen.

Die Serienfertigung – Qualität kennt keine Kompromisse

Die Serien-Fertigung der DeepSight wird biolnic voraussichtlich selbst vornehmen und zusammen mit den Partnern aufbauen.

Denn: Absolut höchste Qualitätsmaßstäbe stehen immer im Vordergrund!

Inhaltsverzeichnis

Unsere tollen Partner

Die enge Zusammenarbeit mit hervorragenden Partnern ermöglicht uns Weltklasse-Arbeit

biolnic wird bei der Entwicklung der Mikrofertigungstechnologien mit kompetenten Partnern aus dem EU-Projekt COTECH kooperieren.

Das COTECH Projekt

biolnic führt die Entwicklungen über akkommodierbare Intraokularlinsen der Firma be innovative basierend auf dem von der Europäischen Union geförderten Projekt COTECH (2008-2012: „Converging technologies for micro systems manufacturing“, www.fp7-cotech.eu) fort. In COTECH wurden von 25 europäischen Partnern völlig neue Mikrofertigungstechnologien entwickelt. Der „Demonstrator“ der be innovative war eine in den Kapselsack implantierbare akkommodierbare IOL mit verformbaren Optiken. Die IOL wurde aus zwei verschieden geformten asphärischen Halbschalen gefertigt und zusammengefügt.


Das Centre for Polymer Micro and Nano Technology an der Universität Bradford (UK) ist seit 2001 international anerkannt für bahnbrechende Forschung im Bereich Mikrospritzguss. Es verfügt über ein umfassendes Sortiment an modernsten Verarbeitungsanlagen, die speziell zur Fertigung von Micro- und Nanopräzisionskomponenten im industriellen Maßstab konzipiert wurde. So wurden maßgeschneiderte Systeme zum Monitoring des Verhaltens von Rohmaterialen und der Maschinendynamik in Produktionsprozessen entwickelt. Weitere neuartige Sensortechnologien und Datenerfassungssysteme ermöglichen eine lückenlose Rückverfolgbarkeit der Produktionsumgebung bei der Produktfertigung. Dies ist besonders in der Medizinproduktbranche von großer Bedeutung. Das Zentrum verfügt außerdem über ein eigens eingerichtetes Labor zur Charakterisierung (z.B. zur Bestimmung von Form und mechanischen Eigenschaften von Mikrogusskomponenten und Oberflächeneigenschaften). Ein hochqualifiziertes Team bietet das zur Entwicklung neuer Verfahren und Technologien benötigte Know-how, um die Herausforderungen zur Herstellung modernster Geräte zu bewältigen.


Das Institut für Mikrosystemtechnik (IMTEK) der Albert-Ludwigs-Universität Freiburg ist ein international führendes Institut auf dem Gebiet der Lebenswissenschaften, Brain-Computer-Interface und der Mikro-/Nanotechnologie. Das IMTEK verfügt über detailliertes Wissen und Erfahrungen im Bereich der Kunststoffabformung mit Sub-Mikrometer Genauigkeit und in der Fertigung von hochpräzisen Spritzgieß- und Prägeformen mit optischen Oberflächen.


Das Institut für Experimentelle Ophthalmologie (Univ.-Prof. Dr. rer. nat. Dr. med. Solon Thanos) ist eine anerkannte Forschungseinrichtung der Westfälischen Wilhelms-Universität Münster. Die Arbeitsgruppe beherrscht das Gebiet der klinischen und experimentellen Ophthalmologie. Bioverträglichkeitsstudien, in vitro Kulturen von Nerven-, Linsen- und Hornhautzellen werden routinemäßig durchgeführt.

Inhaltsverzeichnis

Herausforderungen die zu meistern sind

Große Ideen benötigen starke Strategien zur Verwirklichung

Naturgemäß bestehen bei der Entwicklung von neuen Implantaten für den menschlichen Körper vielfältige medizintechnische Risiken und Herausforderungen:

  • Der Mikrospritzguss hochelastischer optischer Präzisionsbauteile und damit die Fertigung der DeepSight sind äußerst anspruchsvoll, aber mit unseren kompetenten Partnern aus dem COTECH-Projekt umsetzbar.
  • Die Akkommodation der DeepSight muss sich im Rahmen der klinischen Prüfungen am Menschen ausreichend zeigen. Wir sind davon überzeugt, dass dies gelingt.
  • Ferner hängt die präzise Auswahl der korrekten Größe der IOL für den Ziliarmuskel von der Sorgfalt des Arztes und geeigneter bildgebender Verfahren ab. Präzision und Sorgfalt sind Augenärzte jedoch gewöhnt.
  • Das Langzeitverhalten von Implantaten lässt sich generell nie im Voraus 100%ig zuverlässig bewerten. Es sollte jedoch so sein wie bei herkömmlichen IOL’s.

Gewiss soll hier auch darauf hingewiesen werden, dass es bei solchen Projekten vorkommen kann, dass Entwicklungsschritte, Tests oder sogar klinische Prüfungen wiederholt werden müssen. Dies kann im schlimmsten Fall bis zum Scheitern der Unternehmung infolge der Nichterreichung der Verkehrsfähigkeit der Linsen als Medizinprodukte führen, wodurch Ihre Option verloren gehen würde. Wir werden aber selbstverständlich unser Bestes tun, dass dies nicht eintritt, können ein solches worst-case Szenario jedoch keinesfalls sicher ausschließen.

  • Für eine $310 Option (~250€) erhalten Sie 40% Rabatt auf ein Paar IOL bei einer späteren Inanspruchnahme. Sie zahlen bei anvisiertem Verkaufspreis pro Paar von $5.000 (~4.000€) für 2 IOL dann noch $2.690 (~2.150€) [4.000€ - 40% - Optionspreis] und sparen somit $2.000 (~1.600€).

Wir haben uns für US-Dollar als Kampagnen Währung entschieden, da Sie so einfach mit Ihrer Kreditkarte zahlen können, ohne über das Portal Paypal gehen zu müssen.

Mit den obigen Optionen erhalten Sie eine beliebige Ausführung einer akkommodierbaren Intraokularlinse der biolnic. Dies beinhaltet z.B. eine Variante der DeepSight mit UV-Filterschutz oder eine Ausführung, die bestimmte Sehfehler ausgleichen, wie z.B. eine Hornhautverkrümmung (Astigmatismus).

Wie in der Kampagne beschrieben, handelt es sich bei dem DeepSight Projekt um ein Entwicklungsvorhaben, in dem die Verkehrsfähigkeit der DeepSight erlangt werden soll. Einen Erfolg können wir aber nicht garantieren. Für den Fall also, dass uns dies trotz aller gemeinsamen Anstrengungen nicht gelingen sollte, muss die Option leider verfallen. Erwerber außerhalb der EU sind selbst für die Entrichtung einer Mehrwertsteuer verantwortlich (siehe FAQ).
